title: Lesson in stupidity: Savage chop in classroom as schools face first real-time cuts in 20 years
text:
Educating Yorkshire (Photo: Channel 4) Share Get politics   Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Schools face the first real-terms cuts to funding in more than 20 years, experts warn today. 
Spending per pupil is set to plunge by 6.5% by 2019/20 in the latest Tory attack on youngsters, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies. 
And experts have warned classrooms could see more pupils while the number of teachers drops and the loss of teaching assistants altogether. 
Subsidised school trips would face being axed and equipment budgets could also be slashed, forcing kids to study old textbooks and education chiefs to impose a freeze on buying new computers. 
Schools are already scrapping music lessons, turning off heating and planning to charge parents for children’s sessions with mental health counsellors. Theresa May field questions (Photo: Getty) 
And children from poorer backgrounds are already suffering the most as they are less likely to make good progress at secondary school than better-off youngsters, according to a new warning from the Government’s Social Mobility Commission today. 
Skint schools in crisis over £2.5bn Tory cuts as true scale of blitz on budgets is revealed 
The IFS report says: “This will be the first time schools have seen real-terms cuts in spending per pupil since the mid-1990s.” 
One deputy head involved in drawing up school budgets feared cuts of 6.5% could see two more children in every class. 
Recent figures show primary classes had an average of 27.1 children, with and 20.4 in each secondary class. Primary School Children Chasing Each Other in a School Playground (Photo: Getty) 
An expert told the Mirror the scale of the cuts could see primary class sizes rise by 2.1 pupils, and add an extra three kids to secondary classes. 
That would see an average of 23.4 children in secondary classes and 29.2 in primary classes - close to the politically significant level of 30 per class. Read More 
Lib Dem leader Tim Farron accused Theresa May of “waging a war on young people”. 
He said: “These cuts could be the death of education as we know it. 
“Smaller budgets will mean staff redundancies, bigger class sizes and slashing things like the school clothing grants that help some of the poorest pupils. 
“These economies could also mean the end of teaching assistants in the classroom. 
“Young people are already facing up to the possibility of not being able to study, travel and work in mainland Europe. 
“They face huge generational unfairness, great economic uncertainty and now Theresa May is taking away the tools to help to get on in life.” Teenage students in the classroom (Photo: Getty) 
They fear fresh cuts when a new funding formula comes into force in September next year(2018). 
The report comes as the Government’s Social Mobility Commission issues a warning over the lack of progress seen by pupils from poorer backgrounds once they go to secondary school. Read More Theresa May's family coat of arms revealed - the same privilege enjoyed by David Cameron 
It describes the situation as “one of the great injustices” of the education system. 
Since 2012, pupils from low-income families have made less progress year-on-year than classmates from wealthier families, research by LKMco and Education Datalab based on National Pupil Database data shows. 
The gulf is worst for poor white children, with most low-income ethnic minority groups making progress in line with the national average - partly because ethnic minority parents provide more effective home support. 
Social Mobility Commission chair and Labour former Cabinet Minister Alan Milburn said: “One of the shocking features of our education system is that the gap between poor pupils and their better-off peers increases during their time in school rather than reducing. 
“This new research suggests that the progress they make in primary school is all but wiped out during secondary. 
“The consequence is that successive generations of poor kids are being let down by a school system that is supposed to be there to help them move up and get on.” 
Many schools have found themselves in debt in recent years after council-controlled schools were allowed to borrow money to plug gaps under David Cameron ’s government. 
The amount they were given permission to borrow rose from £35.8million to £51.7million between 2013-14 and 2014-15. School children at work in a classroom (Photo: PA) 
But many have been unable to repay their loans and, with teaching staff making up 80% of a school’s costs, unions fears jobs could be cut. 
Research shows the biggest spending rises over the last 20 years have been on schoolchildren in England, with £4,900 currently spent on each primary school pupil and £6,300 spent per secondary student. 
Government statistics last September showed a total of 8.56 million pupils in schools in England - an increase of just over 121,000 pupils, or 1.4%, in 12 months. 
“The total number of pupils has grown every year since 2009 and there are now 467,265 more pupils in schools than at that point,” it said. 
Further education is also facing huge cuts as funding for sixth formers by 2020 will be the same as it was 30 years ago - at the end of Margaret Thatcher’s reign, respected think tank the IFS calculates. 
Further education (FE) Colleges face an ongoing budget squeeze, with spending per student plummeting by 6.7% between 2010/11 and 2015/16 and a further drop of 6.5% expected over the next few years. Educating Essex (Photo: Channel 4) 
It means that funding for 16-18-year-olds is no higher than it was almost 30 years ago. 
Report author and IFS associate director Luke Sibieta said: “Over the next few years, both further education and schools are due to experience cuts. 
“For schools, this comes on the back of very significant increases over the last few decades. 
“For FE, this comes on the back of tight funding settlements for decades that will leave spending per student the same in 2020 as it was in 1990. 
“The lack of priority given to FE by successive governments in spending settlements does not seem sustainable.” 
A Department for Education spokesman said: “School funding is now at its highest level on record at more than £40billion in 2016-17 and the IFS has shown that by 2020 per pupil spending in schools is set to be at least 70% higher in real terms than it was in 1990. 
“We are transforming post-16 education and investing £7billion to ensure there is a place in education or training for every 16 to 19-year-old who wants one.” Cash-strapped head to do marathon to raise cash rather than sack teacher 
Earlier this month, Derbyshire headmaster Dave Shaw revealed he was competing in the Great North Run to raise money for Spire Junior School in Chesterfield, which faces a £17,000 funding cut. 
He said: “We have had to cut staff and various other things, and the next thing would be Year 6 visits, but that’s something we really want to keep hold of. 
“Costs are going up regarding National Insurance contributions and pension contributions, and we are just getting the same amount of income coming in, so we are losing more and more. 
“I’m struggling with how we will do this in the future.” 
Dave’s local MP, Labour’s Toby Perkins, highlighted the school’s plight to Theresa May at Prime Minister’s Questions. 
But the Tory leader told him: “What the government has brought forward is a consultation on a fairer funding formula. 
“We will look at the results of the fairer funding formula consultation and will bring forward our firm proposals in due course.” Dave Shaw is the headteacher of a cash-strapped school 
On his Just Giving fundraising page Mr Shaw writes: 
“As Headteacher of Spire Junior School, I will be running the Great North Run in order to raise funds to subsidise school visits for the children at my school. 
We have 70% of our children on free school meals and are situated in an area of high socio-economic deprivation. Due to funding cuts, and increases in costs we’re finding it increasingly difficult to run the school without running into a deficit. 
Under the new funding formula we will lose £17,000 of our budget and by 2020 the forecast is a loss of £99,000. I’ve had to lose one teacher and one teaching assistant, my deputy is now needed to teach full time, and I’m teaching part time, to save money. 
“Our staff do a fantastic job and go above and beyond for the children and families of this school. If I lost anymore staff then I feel the quality of education our children currently receive would suffer. I have therefore looked at how to cut costs and have had to make some difficult decisions, which has included cutting back subsidies for school visits. 
“I’m trying to be proactive in plugging the funding gap with donations and sponsorship from completing the Great North Run. As we are not a charity this page has been set up as a crowdfunding opportunity. 
“For more information about the school please visit our website www.spirejunior.co.uk We hope you’re able to support the fantastic children and families at our school.” How badly off could our schools be? 
Why are schools losing money? School budgets are failing to keep pace with inflation, meaning rising prices outstrip the amount of cash they have to spend. A new funding formals will also see some schools robbed of hundreds of thousands of pounds. 
How badly off will they be? A report from Whitehall spending watchdog the National Audit Office suggested schools will have to cut £3billion by 2019-20 at a time when pupil numbers are climbing and real terms cash per-pupil is falling. Today’s report from the Institute for Fiscal Studies is the latest study to highlight the looming funding crisis. 
Will some schools gain? Ministers claims half will benefit under the “fairer” formula. But critics say the pot from which money is shared out is not big enough. 
Where can I find out more? The SchoolCuts.org.uk website provides a calculator setting out how badly each school could be clobbered. The Government has also set up a website where users can discover the potential impact of the new formula. Like us on Facebook
